EDVISIT^10776605^Glenn, Olivia^01/14/80^WOODRUFF, FERNE
I saw this patient in conjunction with Dr. Leyva and Dr.
Forrest. I confirm that I have interviewed and examined the
patient, reviewed the resident's documentation on the patient's
chart, and discussed the evaluation, plan of care, and
disposition with the patient.
CHIEF COMPLAINT: A 65-year-old female with difficulty breathing.
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient with known multiple
medical problems presents with difficulty breathing. At her
rehabilitation facility was noted to be hypoxic and thus was sent
here. The patient's recent past medical history is remarkable
for a fall with cervical fractures, rib fractures, and subsequent
hemothorax for which she was admitted to the Educare-Pullman ICU over the
end of December through the beginning of January. The patient's
chest tube was withdrawn approximately 10 days ago and the
patient has been doing well at rehab since. However, today was
noted to have desaturations to 80% on room air. She had
shortness of breath as well. Her oxygen saturations improved
marginally on oxygenation and have been responsive to
nonrebreather treatment in the transport here. The patient was
treated with nebulizers and Lasix without significant improvement
and is noted to be quite tachypneic.
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Remarkable for hypertension, CHF,
diabetes, asthma, chronic renal insufficiency, osteoporosis,
anemia, and cervical fracture.
SOCIAL HISTORY, FAMILY HISTORY, AND REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: Limited
by the severity of the patient's presentation.
MEDICATIONS: Insulin, Zocor, PhosLo, calcium carbonate,
Protonix, Niferex, Norvasc, Fosamax, Epogen, Lasix, lisinopril,
Colace, and Xalatan.
ALLERGIES: Morphine and aspirin.
PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: The patient is awake and alert, in some
degree of respiratory distress, however, able to interact and
answer questions in 1-2 word sentences. Vital signs are as
documented with an elevated blood pressure of 176/96, pulse 76,
and oxygen saturation is 98% on nonrebreather. HEENT exam is
atraumatic, normal to inspection. The patient has a large tongue
and her uvula is not visible at all. Neck is immobilized in a
C-collar and is obese. Respiratory exam reveals decreased breath
sounds diffusely with tachypnea and respiratory muscle accessory
use. Cardiovascular exam: Regular rate and rhythm without
murmur. Pulses are palpable in all four extremities. Abdomen is
soft and nontender, obese, but without any organomegaly or
masses, or guarding, or rebound. Skin is intact, warm, and dry
without any lesions or rash. Musculoskeletal exam reveals
tenderness over the right ribs where the patient has known rib
fractures. Neurologically, she is oriented with difficulty
speaking due to respiratory distress but no focal neurologic
deficit.
LABORATORY STUDIES: BNP is elevated in the 500-600 range. White
blood count is slightly elevated at 10, hematocrit 26.3, which is
at the patient's baseline, and creatinine of 2.2. LFTs within
normal limit. INR 1.2. D-dimer significantly elevated. EKG
demonstrates sinus rhythm with nonspecific ST-T wave changes.
IMAGING STUDIES: Chest x-ray shows bilateral effusions, which
are present previously but possibly slightly increased.
EMERGENCY DEPARTMENT COURSE: The patient was initially given
Lasix and nitro with improvement in her blood pressure and was
also started on CPAP. She seemed to be improving clinically for
some period of time but then began to decline in her mental
status. At that time an ABG was sent demonstrating hypoxia.
Prior to those results, the decision was made that the patient
likely needed intubation. We had hope to hold off to do a
thoracentesis; however, the patient's clinical course declines
such that it was not possible for her to sit up for the
procedure. On CPAP, the patient's oxygen saturations were stable
throughout in the 90s, but she developed increasing respiratory
distress. Intubation was complicated by her inability to flex
her neck, her large tongue, and her body habitus; was successful
in two attempts with one episode of bag mask ventilation in
between those attempts. For full details of the procedure,
please see the attached procedure note. Thoracic Surgery was
consulted. They arrived as the patient was being intubated. At
this time their recommendation is for a CT scan of the chest to
determine whether this is more likely a hemothorax or a pleural
effusion and whether it is loculated. This study will be
performed and then patient will be admitted to her ready bed in
the ICU. A bedside ultrasound was also performed by myself and
the resident demonstrating no obvious pericardial effusion.
******** Not reviewed by Attending Physician ********
PRIMARY DIAGNOSIS: Bilateral pleural effusions.
SECONDARY DIAGNOSIS: Respiratory distress.
TERTIARY DIAGNOSIS: Question recurrent hemothorax versus pleural
effusion.
FOURTH DIAGNOSIS: Question CHF.
DISPOSITION: Admitted to the ICU.
CRITICAL CARE TIME: 75 minutes.
